captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: All right, let's
make some noise.
[LAUGH]
My name is Mike Musto.

Each week, I travel the country
with the goal of

showcasing the best and baddest
muscle cars and hot
rods around.

Every car has a past and
every owner, a story.

Welcome to the world
of "Big Muscle."

All right, I figured, if we're
going to do a car review,
let's do a car review.

We're behind the wheel of a 1955
Buick Special with a 502
cubic inch big block.

We're pushing about 600
horsepower and about 650 pound
feet of torque.

And oh my god, does
it feel like it.

When you think about the Buick
Special, you don't really

think about a car that's, I
don't know, super stylish.

You might think of, say,
a 1955 Chevy, or
a 1957 Chevy Belair.

The Buick Special
was kind of--

it was downplayed
a little bit.

It wasn't the car that
everybody wanted.

Now, you've got to
remember that the
Special was a post car.
Now, what does post car mean?

Well, you've got, in the
back window, you
actually have a post.
It's not an open window.

So when you roll the front
window and the back window

down, it's not completely
open.
There's that post there.
It was the cheapest line.

The next one up would have
been a Buick Century.

And after that, you would
have the Roadmaster.

The Roadmaster is the
big money car.

However, the Special is the
one that's really nice.

Because of this window post,
you've got certain things like
silence, right?

You've got window channels where
the windows actually go

up, lock into the channels, and
you don't hear anything.

Thad and I are driving right
now, and it is an unbelievably

windy day, and it's silent in
this car, which is wonderful.

It's something that we don't
experience that much.

And you guys out there, that
are like, oh, it's got a
little wind noise or whatever.
That's fine--

you don't realize how much wind
noise affects you until

you go on a three, to four,
to five hour trip.

You get fatigued and it really
does kind of beat you up.

Now, this car is huge
on the inside.
You're looking at me.
I've got legroom.
I'm sitting back.
Thaddeus is next to me.
He's comfortable.

I feel like the front seat was
designed by the same guy who

designed the Barcalounger, or
the couch in your house.

It is so comfortable, and I love
it because so many of the

cars that we drive are
so uncomfortable.

And I'm wedged in there, or
Thad's wedged in there.

And we do these shoots,
and it's difficult.
This car is fantastic.
You know what I mean?
Comfort all day long.

When I approached Harry about
filming this car, he
immediately said yes.

Thankfully for us, he
was a fan of this
show, which was great.
And he said, you know what?
Take the car.
Enjoy it.

And he goes, but make sure
you do one thing--

he goes, drive it like
it was yours.

Now, a lot of the owners that
we interview, and whose cars

we drive, let us drive
the cars, obviously.
And we're very--

obviously, we're careful with
everything that we use.

Harry just like, make sure you
show the potential of the car.

Make sure you drive the car to
the point where people get the

idea of what I've done and the
fact that you can actually

build a car that's 65 years
old that not only can you

drive it for 300, 400, 500
miles, but that you have full

reliability, that you
have fuel economy,
that you have comfort.

And that's what he did
with this car.

HARRY FISHER: You know Mike, I
focus on driveability because
I think that's primary.
I mean, my cars look good.

But if you can't drive
them, again,
they're not worth anything.

I mean, I concentrate
on a car that will--

it'll stop, it'll accelerate,
it'll corner, it'll be
comfortable, it'll be safe.
And that's first.

Anybody can make something
pretty, but it can be the most

dangerous car out there
on the road.
Not my cars.

Well, the modifications to the
drive train and suspension,

first of all, was that this
car was a 70% car.

And it needed some work
when I got it.

So the engine needed
to be all--

I mean, it's an amazing
engine--
502 fuel injected ramjet.

The guy before me spent $10,000
trying to bring it up
to 600 horsepower.
Is it 600 horse?
I don't know.
It doesn't matter.
It runs really good.

But when I got it, the valve
covers were leaking.
The intake was leaking.
The pan was smashed.

A couple hundred bucks, I fixed
all of those things.

The 700 R4 was shifting
a little ragged.

Took it out to Larry at
Vintage Transmission.
Thing shifts good now.
It's reliable.
It works all the time.

Back end four link
was falling off.
Took it off, rewelded
everything, put it back together.
And the car is sound.
It's fit.
It work.

And I probably didn't spend
$3,000 to make it
what it is right now.

MIKE MUSTO: Harry Fisher, the
owner of this car, has a

little different philosophy on
buying cars than most people.

This car, he's only had
for about a year.

And let me give you
the reason why--
Harry is a true hot rodder.

He's been in cars
his whole life.

Works on cars, does
things like that.

Was in the industry for
quite some time.

But his philosophy is, I'm
not going to build a car.
OK, Harry, well why is that?

His whole thing was, well, why
am I going to take the hit?

Why am I going to build a car
that's $100,000, when I can

let somebody else spend $100,000
and then buy that

same car when it's not
quite finished.
And then he takes them over.
And he finishes them.

And in the end, he makes
a wonderful machine.

You know, he's got power
steering in here.

And yes, the power steering is,
as you could tell, very,
very light.

Thaddeus is bouncing around
like a bowl of jello.

But the power steering
is very light.

He's gone through a four
wheel disk conversion.

So when you hit the brake pedal,
it brings the car down.

There's not any drama where the
car pulls to the right, or

pulls to the left, it just stops
straight and true, which
is really, really nice.
And it's as you'd expect.

But as you'd expect is not
something that a lot of people
can achieve.

That only comes with
time, effort, and
really driving the car.

One of the nicest part about
the cars from the late '40s

and the '50s are
the interiors.

Harry, he kept the stock
gauges, but he had the
internals redone.

So everything looks
period correct.
It's beautiful.

All the bright work
is wonderful.

He added a vintage AC system
that cools the car down
wonderfully.

You have this beautifully
painted
dash, dashboard, clock--
everything is just nice.

And it's kind of as you would
expect this car to feel if you

were to go back into a
dealership in 1955.

Obviously, like we said, this
thing's got performance.

Now Harry, being Harry, was just
great about letting us
drive the car and use the car.

The cool part is, I mean, you
could drop this thing down.

And it's got so much torque that
when you gas it, [LAUGH]
it's got so much power.
I'm not giving this car back.

This one might come
home with me.
This thing is bitching, dude.
And it drives like a sofa.

It's like the world's fastest
toaster oven.

HARRY FISHER: This thing
caught my eye
because it was different.
It has style.
I loved the two tone.
It's just fun.

I don't like a huge car, and
yet I've got a 20 foot

Cadillac El Dorado
convertible.

And I love that car, but it's
a 20 foot Cadillac El Dorado
convertible.
This is a 3,800 pound hot rod.
And I love it.

And I love it because
it's different.

Kids tell me they can't
afford a hot rod.
Well, sure you can.

Again, you don't have to
have $100,000 hot rot.
Get a $2,000 Ford Galaxy.
There's a good start.
It's the beginning.
Start your passion.
Start your love.
And then make the car yours.

Do little things to
make it your car--
not somebody else's car.
Make it your car.

MIKE MUSTO: So you guys might
remember that the last car we

drove that was from, like, the
late '40s, early '50s, was
that 1949 Dodge Wayfarer.

That was also just a wonderful,
wonderful car.

And I'm liking these kind
of '40s and '50s
cars more and more.

I mean, I'm really starting to
appreciate the curvature of

the fenders, and the bright
work, and the chrome, and the
interior work.

They come from a time period
where the muscle cars that we

feature, like the Chargers,
and the Camaros, and the

Mustangs still have a somewhat
modern feel to them.

These cars from an era that is
completely different, right?

Some eras of cars are just
physically and stylistically
more in depth than others.

And the '50s cars and the
'40s cars kind of
fit that bill, man.
Really, really nice rides.
Is that chick in the Solara?
Say hi.
What are you doing?
You want to be on video?
-What?

MIKE MUSTO: Want
to be on video?

-That's what I thought
you were doing
because I saw the camera.

I think we might have
[INAUDIBLE] you back there.

MIKE MUSTO: You did
[INAUDIBLE] us.
-We did.
MIKE MUSTO: Oh, we noticed.
-That's a sexy car.

MIKE MUSTO: It is a sexy
car, isn't it?
-It's a sexy car.

MIKE MUSTO: Yeah, it's
pretty slick.
All right, guy, see you later.
-OK.

HARRY FISHER: You know,
I wish I knew.

I could never figure out why
somebody would spend $150,000

on a car and sell
it for $27,000.

But you'd probably
have to ask them.

Thankfully, I'm at the
receiving end.

Like I said earlier, let
somebody else spend $50,000,

think with your head, not
with your emotions.

It took me five months to get
this car, five months of
negotiating.

And I wanted this car really,
really bad from the
first time I saw it.

And I'd have probably
spent $10,000 more
for it than I did.
But it was worth the wait.

Look at today, what this
car made possible.

I wouldn't be here without
this 55 Buick.

I'd probably be sitting at
home eating oatmeal.
This is a lot more fun.

MIKE MUSTO: I spent 10 hours
behind the wheel of this 1955
Buick Special today.

As you can tell, the
sun's going down.
And we're all pretty tired.

The nice part about this
car, though, is, it
played so many roles.
It played part couch.
It played part corner carver.

It was an insane burnout
machine, thanks to the 502 big
block in this thing.

I was probably drive this
car on a daily basis.
That's how easy it was.

The power steering, the fuel
injection, the air

conditioning, the fact that when
you roll the windows up,
they are tight.
And they seal.

And you can hear yourself not
only talk but think about the
drive that you're on.

Look at this car, think about
what we said on how it was

built, and you can use it as a
model because this is what a
good hot rod should be.

Guys, thanks for tuning in
to "Big Muscle." We'll
see you next week.

A car like this, you drive
all day, and you
have power to use.
Look at all these boats.
That's cool.

I feel like there are squatters
on these boats.
-I do too.
MIKE MUSTO: Right?

I feel like there are
people like--

we're driving along this place
where there's all these kind
of derelict boats.

And I'm thinking people
are doing bad
things in those things.
Dude, this is the sketchiest--

-Dude you have not
been to Florida.

MIKE MUSTO: This reminds
me of Florida.

I feel like I'm driving
down the Panhandle.
Where the [BLEEP]
are we?

-We're out along some
river, dude.

It's like Redneck Riviera
out here.
MIKE MUSTO: Dude--
[LAUGH]

show and shine or a rat rod themed primer car﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:
My father bought a new Buick Special 2 door sedan in 1955 for $2500 (still 
have receipt). It was green with ivory top, sounded like a boat and stalled 
a lot, but 4 kids and a German shepherd fit in the back seat.  Loved this 
video, thanks﻿

comments.author: Mark Rookus

comments.text:
valve cover gaskets go bad and leak.  Re-use of said gaskets can also cause 
said problem, and that is not unheard of at all.  The smashed oil pan would 
also be a good indication of having been driven hard and abused.

comments.text:

Imperial.﻿

comments.text:
You obviously didn't have the right Buick. I've had a 2007 Lucerne since in 
was new and haven't had a thing go wrong with it. It's a great car. My 
son's VW Jetta Turbo was a piece of crap.
comments.author: William H. Burke, Jr.

comments.text:
I owned a 1985 buick regal limited that had been severely mistreated, it 
had 175k miles and it showed it. Except the engine, a 4.4L v6, was as solid 
as can be. That car did not leak at all compared to my sister's 2006 VW bug 
that dumped oil all over her driveway(a known issue with bugs, and alot of 
other precision machined vehicles). A lot of cars leak fluid and that is 
just from general wear, if you dont take care of your car it wont take care 
of you. its as simple as that, and if the buick's you saw "PISS{ed} OIL AND 
FLUID EVERY WHERE!!!" then it was the owners fault, and if that owner was 
you then im sorry that you have a ridiculous bias against a solid 
manufacturer because of your own neglect.

around and they can fit the same engines as their more expensive counter 
parts i mentioned.  start with something and make it yours,  not someone 
elses'  ﻿

comments.author: nezerac

comments.text:
I like a post car. They're usually less expensive than hardtops, they cut 
down the wind noise, and the posts make the body structure more solid.  If 
the car ever rolls over it will give more protection to the occupants of 
the car. On the other hand, the 2 door hardtop generally look better with 
all the windows down. There's trade offs and it's just a matter of what you 
prefer. Nice car!﻿
comments.author: DougCameraMan

comments.text:
Just about the most well done car I've seen since the show started. It's as 
perfect as perfect gets...which is perfect. And I love that its got a 
proper big block, not a dreary LS motor. ﻿
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text: +heyitschinoable Idiot.
comments.author: Nonya Bidness

comments.text: +Alec D. Tell em Alec, ls really are DREARY, OVER HYPED AND CLICHE.
comments.author: heyitschinoable

comments.text: +Nonya Bidness Thanks. And go fuck yourself.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text: +Alec D. Pure ignorance.
comments.author: Nonya Bidness

comments.text:
+lpatierno84 It is dreary. They put those motors in pick up trucks. The 5.3 
may have a different intake, but it feels hardly different than an LS3. 
They've got diesel like acceleration. Very smooth, but very boring.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text:
+Alec D. You're so right! The 770hp lsx454 is totally dreary especially for 
a "stock" motor as you'd call it. You're also right about me have a ls in 
my car. I have a 5.3 mated to a zf6 in a tube chassis 49 Chevy rat rod.... 
so dreary...
comments.author: lpatierno84

comments.text:
+lpatierno84 What difference does that make? It's still a stock motor; it's 
still stock when you drop it in your car. Not that you personally would 
because you'd probably be like everyone else and put an LS motor in your 
car.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text: +Alec D. That's a crate motor
comments.author: lpatierno84

comments.text: +lpatierno84 A 502 big block.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text: +Alec D. And what is fun to drive in stock form??
comments.author: lpatierno84

comments.text:
+lpatierno84 They're just not fun to drive. At least in stock form they 
aren't. Plus so many guys put them in their muscle cars. It's almost a 
cliche.
comments.author: Alec D.

comments.text: What's dreary about a ls motor??
comments.author: lpatierno84

comments.text:
I like the motivation from Harry, makes me want to start a budget project - 
why not?  Also what he said reminds me of a guy I knew who paid over 100k 
to have a mustang built up and months after completion sold it for less 
than half that... I never understood that, but it's interesting if like 
Harry you're on the buying end!﻿
comments.author: Rick James

comments.text:
He made an excellent point in that some folks will start a rod and spend 
moogoo $$ on it only to later tire of it or more likely have uh er their 
significant other to tire of it ir make a baby and decide to unload it 
quick and cheap. You can even get a "basket case cheaper still if you are 
willing t get help or learn to rebop a Nailhead or old Rocket engine and 
larn to red brakeswhich is just aout imperative what with these old 4 wheel 
drums taking 225 feet to stop in 60 mph traffic and many will forget the 
inferior stopping power if old drums and the tendency of those 50s and 60s 
cars to nosedip severely , slide and swap ends on a really long skid/stop 
rendering your steering irrelevan.....until that moron in front of you 
stops on a dime and throws 9 cents back at you. BUT if you wanna be the 
coolest cruiser on the Blvd Friday Night go retro with safety updates and 
all the girls will wanna ride in your car...if you wife notwithstanding a 
la American Graffiti when Cindy Williams character wanted to make Ron 
Howards character jealous and almost got kilted with Harrison Fords 
character Bob Falfa or Alafalfa back from his hiatus from Spanky and the 
little rascals LOL. Rock and Rod On forever.
 See if you can adapt a Columbia  speed rear end to your Buick and make 
automotive history or at least a Winters, Halibrand or other quick change 
and eke your mileage up if you can keep your foot off the firewall. Little 
Deuce Coupe to you all.

comments.text:
I darn sure don't need no one to build my motors, and don't even try to 
lecture me on turbos when I was racing turbo Buicks 25 years ago. Blah blah 
blah 20 mpg my friends car I referenced gets better. LOL but you know him 
and everything about that car and you know something bout everything..NOT. 
You can't comprehend or obviously read for that matter I don't like 
chebbys, PERIOD. Just cause all the redecks-inbreeds think they are great 
doesn't mean I do. I like Ford and Dodge, 2nd to Buick. I have to go buy 
one of them new cause I can't buy a new Buick no longer thanks to Generic 
Morons killing the brand years ago Darn sure don't want the name only 
slapped on a Crapillac with a chebby motor.. Yes a Buick 350 is the same as 
a 231 GN motor and responds to turbos and nitrous well and has been proven. 
Also is 200lbs or more lighter than a chebby with a longer stroke. I can 
make a Buick just as fast as any chebby for the same money cause I know 
these engines and where to source parts..they don't cost no different maybe 
not every single part but heads, cams, etc, all cost the same. People that 
don't know and 1st thought is put a chebby in it can research vendors for 
parts, machine shops, etc to find out whats out there. I only send my 
motors needing machine work to machine shops that are Buick people. I have 
no argument, I stated facts and how I feel, nothing to argue. You are the 
one who started carrying on like a kid
 Typical chebby rehtoric I can buy parts at Wal-Mart, I darn sure don't 
want to buy parts there
comments.author: buickdude69

comments.text:
As for "proving what I don't know about Buicks", first off I'm not sure 
what you mean by that. I never said anything specific about Buicks. If 
anything you made it apparent that you know absolutely nothing about Chevy 
motors. You also made it apparent that you know nothing about engines in 
general. "my buddy has a 8 second street car". "I know vendors and can make 
a 3000 HP engine". "Chevys suck". Real intelligent argument you have there.
comments.author: yamahondarider

comments.text:
I never bashed Buicks. I have two Olds 350s in my cars. Nothing wrong with 
them. Its just easier and cheaper to make power with a Chevy. It'll always 
be that way and you can't argue against it. I've told you before I'm not 
saying Buicks can't make power but you can't seem to understand that your 
the only one bashing a brand here. A 9 second car isn't amazing. A 9 second 
daily driver with 20+ MPG in total street car form for under $4000 
including the car is fairly impressive. And your wrong actually, the first 
turbocharged car was the 1962 Oldsmobile Turbo Jetfire. Buick made one hell 
of a car with the Grand National though, one of my favorites. Too bad their 
$12,000+ for a nice one. An old stock iron block iron headed Buick 350 with 
a turbo bolted on won't make near as much power as a stock aluminum headed 
5.3 Vortec with a turbo bolted on. Like I said before, any engine can make 
stupid power with enough money. You sure as shit could make 800 WHP with a 
turbo Buick 350 but you'd spend more doing it. Generalizing of course, an 
engine gets its power from the heads and the cam. the LSX platform has 
great heads stock out of the factory. Truck cams leave some to be desired, 
but are better than stock 40+ year old BOP cams. Its just how it is.
comments.author: yamahondarider

comments.text:
Nothing backfired, you just keep proving what your DON'T know about Buicks. 
You think that impresses me? Buick 350 or 455 with a turbo can do same 
thing. Get a clue. Your talking like 8 or 9 seconds 1/4 mile is a big deal 
and I know plenty of Buick street cars and some daily driver Buicks that 
run that. A friend of mine ran 8.50s 1/4 mile and drove the car 60 miles 
daily.. big friggen deal. Let me hand you a tissue, I know the truth hurts 
but I tell you what, come to some of the Buick events, find out whats 
really out there and happening then you can get a real clue what's going on 
in the Buick world. Remember, Buick was playing with turbos back in the day 
and the idiots at chebby were clueless about them. Turbo or pro charger 
Buicks.. no big deal, they are on the streets every day. They will always 
be the minority, but they are out there.
comments.author: buickdude69

comments.text:
The level of stupidity in that last comment was pretty ridiculous. You're 
just angry now. Theres a 3500 LB Ford Fairmont with a 5.3 truck motor, not 
an LS1, cam and turbo only running 9 second quarter mile times on a 235 
radial. Full bodied Chevelle with a twin turbo 6.0 truck motor running 9's. 
Its not rocket science, these are full bodied full interior street cars 
with $500 junkyard motors pulling 9 second quarter mile times using ebay 
parts. People are taking junkyard 5.3 truck motors, turbocharging them, 
getting 20+ MPG and running 10 second times for under $3000, or less than a 
set of heads, a cam, and an intake for your 455. Don't be mad cause power 
comes cheaper with an LSX based powerplant, and you get the benefits of 
reliability, fuel mileage, and easily/cheaply replaced parts. The 
technology is just better. Its a fact, not an opinion. Its not really fair 
comparing a 1999+ engine with a 1970's engine but you brought up the 
comparison, not me. Sorry if it backfired for you.
comments.author: yamahondarider

comments.text:
Once again, showing your ignorance what you DON'T KNOW about Buicks and 
they don't have to be race engines to be all that. $30,000 MY ASS!! Go take 
your stock ls1, strip it down to a rolling beer can like the ricers do, and 
come follow this 4,200 lb  Buick thru town, lights and traffic, ride down 
the interstate, then get that ass kicked. Oh that's right, your stock ls1 
is bad when it weighs 1,500 lbs with driver.. race car
comments.author: buickdude69

comments.text:
I never said there aren't 1500 HP Buick racing engines out there. With that 
said theres also 1500 HP 4 cylinder engines. Anythings possible with enough 
money, and time, and resources. Save up $30,000 and go pay your "vendors" 
and builder to build you a 5 MPG 1500 HP high strung Buick race engine. 
Super Chevy magazine took a stock 4.8 Vortec, smallest of the line up. Put 
an LSXR intake on it and ported the heads. Put 26 lbs of boost thru it from 
a 76mm turbo and made 1203 HP. A monkey could do that on a shoestring 
budget. The article is easily found on Google, if you can figure out how to 
use that. Everyone has preferences. Don't make ignorant blanket statements 
about other brands just because you like another powerplant better. Its 
idiotic. Your only argument so far is "Chevy motors are stupid because 
their stupid". Get a grip.
comments.author: yamahondarider

comments.text:
Moronic is redneck chebby dumbass that don't have since enough to find the 
right vendors, engine builders, etc, they just stand their with tobacco 
juice dripping from their mouth and say lets put a chebby in this Buick. 
What's hilarious is seeing Buick body with chebby motor get it's ass kicked 
by a Buick motor afterwards. I can't wait to start my project, 1,500hp 
Buick V8 in a Camaro. You wanna see hate? Then you'll see some chebby boys 
with them feelings hurt. I've seen it all to often, in the past, this time 
I'm giving them a taste of their own. I've been called a lot of things but 
I know more about Buicks then you ever dreamed of. Cause you don't have 
since to learn about them and hide behind chebby rhetoric reveals what a 
IDiOT you are.
comments.author: buickdude69

comments.text:
With enough money you can make tons of power with any motor. You and people 
like you are a disgrace to the car scene, going around babbling talking 
shit about things you don't even understand. Why all the hate? How can you 
walk around so angry all the time? You don't like Chevys? Thats fine. But 
its a blatant moronic thing to say that their bad engines because the fact 
of the matter is they simply aren't. To say otherwise, and to say putting a 
non-buick motor in that car ruins it makes you a pig headed ignorant fool 
and you don't know your ass from a hole in the ground. Some advice I've 
always stood by is don't argue with an idiot, they'll drag you down to 
their level and beat you with experience. So, I'm not gonna waste my time 
here trying to make you realize how stupid you sound.
comments.author: yamahondarider

comments.text:
+yamahondarider  I don't have to explain nothing to you. I don't like em, 
they do nothing for me. I'm not like everyone in the trailer park, I think 
for my self, and know I have other options. LSX=JOKE. I can make 2-3,000 hp 
with a Buick aluminum 455 block that came from the Buick molds and that is 
proven so whoopty freaking doo. I can get a set of bad ass Buick aluminum 
heads assembled for $1,500 the same it cost for boat anchor chebbys. I know 
these engines, I know the Buick vendors and where to turn to get what I 
need. You don't have a leg to stand on with me
comments.author: buickdude69

comments.text:
Thats a horrible explanation of your viewpoint. You still haven't provided 
a single actual reason you have a problem with Chevy engines. Most 
aftermarket support, they're incredibly reliable with infinite power 
potential, and thats talking about regular old small blocks from the 60s 
and 70s, being fair since Buick doesn't have anything fair to compare to an 
LSX powerplant. I can buy an Edelbrock Performer intake right off the shelf 
of the local autozone for an SBC for $140. I wanted the same manifold for 
the 350 Rocket in my Oldsmobile. How much? $269 and I had to order it 
online. Parts for BOP engines are more expensive and much less available. 
The 350 is coming out of my Cutlass and being replaced with a 5.3 or 6.0 
out of a Chevy truck for good reason.
comments.author: yamahondarider

+WickedTornado LOL.  Maybe.  If you had a maximum 20 minute commute.  Don't

comments.author: Bartholomew Higgins

comments.text:
I suppose that would depend on how far you had to commute each day and 
where you had to park it, etc. I think what he is saying is that he's 
impressed with the way the Buick has been upgraded from the stodgy old 
clunker that it used to be. He's impressed that the fuel mileage is much 
better than he imagined it would be, thanks to modern computer system fuel 
management, and it stops wonderfully with the disc brakes all around. I'll 
bet it's a WHOLE lot safer than a Prius or a Celica or something small like 
that in the event of a hard accident. So really....maybe it IS a darn good 
commuter car??

comments.text:
It would not be like you were in 1955. The hot rod steering wheel changes 
the picture of the interior. Stiff suspension, eliminating the torque tube, 
stiffer shocks, disc brakes change the feel of cars ALOT. The motor has to 
rev to much to get to power bands over the factory nailhead. The factory 
dynaflow was a fluid shift transmission (the only true automatic. Many 
tried and came close but none got quite as good shift feel as a dynaflow). 
Sorry but that is a modern car with a 55 shell on it.
comments.author: HotRod Buick

comments.text:
Comfort in cars doesn't exist anymore, like everything else that was good 
is now gone.
comments.author: SV Nostalgi

comments.text:
Every time I find a error in the narrator I will make a separate post. 
Since I already posted 1 the second is about the line up in 1955. First is 
Special, Then Century (small body with bigger 322), THEN the Super (low end 
big body with big motor), THEN the Roadmaster. This guy needs to do his 
homework.
comments.author: HotRod Buick

comments.text:
BULLSHIT. The 55 Buick was a car everyone wanted thats why was it the 3rd 
best selling car in the world in 1955. Most would've had a Buick over a 
Chevy if they could afford it. 55 Chevy 265 (162-195 HP, 257-260 ft lbs 
torque.) 55 Buick Special 264 nailhead (forged crank, 188 HP, 256ft lbs 
torque base line motor). I own a 56 Chevy w/ 265 and 59 Buick with 364. 
Past owned Chevys: 3 57s, 58, 72 with 235s, 283s, and a 350. Past owned 
Buicks: 2 58s, 4 59s. Buick stomped Chevy from this time period.
comments.author: HotRod Buick

comments.text:
oh man, episodes like this with cars like this make me not want to have

but i'd much rather drive a car like this.
